title: Conclusion to test of proportion having good day

content.description: A research organization reported that <math alttext="41" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>41</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> percent of adults who were asked to describe their day responded that they were having a good day rather than a typical day or a bad day. To investigate whether the percent would be different for high school students, <math alttext="600" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>600</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> high school students were randomly selected. When asked to describe their day, <math alttext="245" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>245</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> students reported that they were having a good day rather than a typical day or a bad day.
content.question: Do the data provide convincing statistical evidence that the proportion of all high school students who would respond that they were having a good day is different from <math alttext="0.41" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>0.41</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> ?

choices.label: No, because the <math alttext="p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value is less than any reasonable significance level.
No, because the <math alttext="p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value is greater than any reasonable significance level.
Yes, because the <math alttext="p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value is less than any reasonable significance level.
Yes, because the <math alttext="p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value is greater than any reasonable significance level.

Yes, because the expected value of the number of students who will report having a good day is <math alttext="246" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>246</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, not <math alttext="245" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>245</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: No, because the <math alttext="p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value is greater than any reasonable significance level.

skill.text: Skill 4.E: Justify a claim using a decision based on significance tests.
